This line will load the bootstrap.xsl stylesheet, which will
cause the opml to load in our UI chrome.
This means a user can give an OPML url, such as
http://foobar.com/hydesign.opml, and instead of returning XML we
will transform it into an HTML file with our Ajax UI.
This allows us to not need a server side for phase 1.
PHP file that does cross-host inclusions
This is a simple PHP file that securely proxies requests to
third party hosts when fetching foreign OPML files - an optional
file, HyperScope will run without this, it just can not do
An Apache module that can create 'friendlier' URLs on a website,
We use mod_rewrite in two cases:
/get/ - We rewrite the proxy.php URL to be at /get/ so it is at
a cleaner address and independent of the backend technology
/hyperscope/ - We 'host' hyperscope at this address to have a
consistent URL for getting hyperscope resources

Our native file format is OPML 2.0, documented at
OPML is a simple XML-based file format the has existed for
several years, and which can model an outline document with HTML
and hyperlinks mixed into the outline nodes. It was created by
Dave Weiner, author of RSS and XML-RPC, two successful
OPML is very easy to work with using XPath, XSLT, and the DOM,
We add a number of custom attributes and tags to OPML 2.0 that
are specific to HyperScope; these are all in the namespace
usually preceded with the namespace identifier "hs:",
Custom tags added to the opml:head section
Custom attributes inside opml : body area
Note: Whether this node had an INCLUDE in it, and it's contents
were replaced with the remote include's contents
We will use OPML 2.0s 'include' link type for include links. The
We will add one custom attribute: hs:include-type, which can be
of three values: branch, plex, node
If this attribute is left off, it defaults to node.
See http://www.opml.org/spec2#inclusion for details on how OPML

We need to support Augment markers in OPML.
This is done simply by using embedded A NAME anchors in our
These embedded links must be generated by the server-side
transformers, surrounding the letter that was marked.
We also have a number of private attributes that are added to
the OPML DOM during Location resolution, specifically on
opml:outline elements; these are used in the final rendering and
jumping phases to display a document. These values should never
appear in public OPML documents. They are located in the

The Dojo Toolkit - general DHTML framework
Sarissa - Utility library for working with XML, XPath, and XSLT
